awd_titl_txt: Probing Gravitational Physics with Event Horizon Telescope and Gravitational Wave Observations of Black Holes
awd_abstract_narration:
Lia Medeiros is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the Institute for Advanced Study.  She will use numerical simulations to fit high-resolution black hole images obtained with the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) and test how gravity is modified near a black hole, as predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity.  As a complementary test of general relativity, she will simulate electromagnetic counterparts of gravitational wave events such as black hole mergers, and she will use these simulations to predict signatures of merger events.  Alongside this research, she will develop hands-on educational activities for middle school students to improve their potential recruitment and retention in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).

The proposed research program seeks to advance our understanding of gravity using observations of black holes and electromagnetic counterparts of gravitational waves.  Medeiros proposes to test general relativity by comparing numerical ray tracing, radiative transfer, and general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations with observations.  She will use EHT observations to derive a set of general relativistic spacetime metrics that deviate from the standard Kerr metric.  She will also use time-dependent GRMHD simulations to generate images and spectra for comparison with observations of merger events.  The educational component of her work involves computer coding classes and enrichment activities for local middle school students, with an emphasis on increasing the participation of girls in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a Postdoctoral Fellowship that supported one postdoctoral scholar for three years. The project focused on developing a new machine learning algorithm for analyzing data from the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), carrying out new tests of gravity with the EHT, and developing a new code to simulate the emission and propagation of light from binary accreting black holes.

New machine-learning algorithm for interferometric data (PRIMO): As part of this fellowship I have developed principal-component interferometric modeling (PRIMO) a novel machine-learning algorithm that uses a vast library of high-resolution, and high-fidelity simulations (developed as part of the project) as a training set. PRIMO results in significant improvement to image fidelity, and allows us to generate images with the full resolution of the array. I have applied PRIMO to both synthetic data as well as real EHT data. A new image of M87 will be published shortly and will be added to this report. 

New tests of gravity in previously unexplored regimes: During this fellowship I simulated the observational appearance of black holes that deviate away from our expectations. If the theory of general relativity is correct, then we know that black holes in space must have a very specific geometry. I simulated over 30,000 black holes that have different geometries and then used the results of these simulations to rule out large parts of the simulation library. This allowed us to perform the first two tests of gravity in the strong field regime with images of supermassive black holes. Our new tests of gravity with both the black hole in M87, and the black hole in our own galaxy (Sgr A*) are comparable in precision to tests with gravitational waves, and are hundreds of times more stringent than solar system tests. As part of this project, I co-lead the EHT’s testing gravity paper for Sgr A*, announced at an NSF press conference in May of 2022.

Simulating emission from binary accreting black holes: As part of the project, I acted as the primary advisor for two masters students. One of my students developed a new code that can simulate the emission and propagation of light from two black holes that are accreting matter while orbiting around each other. The algorithm is written in python, making it easier for young students to use the code. Python tends to be slower than some other programing languages, but we were able to maintain efficiency by using the JAX automatic-differentiation framework, developed by Google. JAX can run in parallel on both CPUs and GPUs and can automatically take derivatives of the functions needed for the simulations. The new algorithm is built for arbitrary spacetimes and can be used to simulate the emission from binary black holes as well as singular black holes. 

Broader Impacts: I developed astronomy-focused curriculum for middle and high-school students that uses hands-on activities and experiments to engage students. I taught both middle and high school students in the local school district, with a particular focus on closing the achievement gap for low-income students.
